metadata.chief_complaint: pre-K physical, mom re-asks about vaccine safety, needs 3 shots, vision/hearing referrals

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi Zoe, hi Mom! Big day, getting ready for pre-K!

script.speaker: child
script.text: I'm gonna go to big kid school!

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's so excited. We're here for her school physical. She needs the form filled out.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Absolutely. Let me see how she's doing first. Any concerns since her last visit?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No, she's healthy. I'm just nervous about the shots. How many does she need today?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: At four years, she'll need DTaP, polio, and MMR. So three injections.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Three? That seems like a lot. Is that safe?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It's very safe. These are boosters of vaccines she's already had, so her immune system recognizes them. It just boosts her protection.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Do I have to get shots?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, sweetie, but they're quick. You're a brave girl.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She had a fever after her last shots. Will that happen again?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It might. A low fever for a day or two is normal. You can give Tylenol if she's uncomfortable.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What about that MMR vaccine? I've heard things about that one.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: The MMR is very safe. The study that claimed it caused autism was fraudulent and has been completely discredited. Millions of kids get MMR safely every year.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Are you sure it's okay to give all three at once?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, I'm sure. This is the standard schedule used nationwide. It's the safest and most effective approach.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Now let me check her vision and hearing.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Zoe, can you point to the pictures I point to? Good. Now cover this eye.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hmm. She's having trouble with the smaller pictures on the left eye. Let me try again.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Is something wrong?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Her right eye reads 20/30 which is okay for her age, but the left is only 20/50. I'd like her to see an eye doctor for a full exam.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Does she need glasses?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Possibly. The optometrist will do a more thorough evaluation. I'll put in a referral today.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. What about her hearing?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me check that now. Zoe, raise your hand when you hear the beep.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: She's passing on the right. And the left. Hearing is fine.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Good. Back to the vaccines, you're really sure they're safe together?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes. I promise you, I give these same vaccines to hundreds of kids. They're safe.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let me do her physical exam.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Heart and lungs sound great. Belly is soft. She looks healthy.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Height and weight are both around 60th percentile. Growing well.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Can I get a copy of the school form?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'll complete it and the front desk will give you a copy. Any restrictions on activities?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No, she can do everything.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Great. So to summarize: she's getting three vaccines today, I'm referring her to the optometrist for the left eye, and I'll complete the school form.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: And if she gets a fever tonight, Tylenol?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, Tylenol or Motrin is fine.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Thank you. Sorry for asking so many questions.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Never apologize for that. It's your job to ask questions. The nurse will be in with the vaccines.
